title: 107_s2014
content: The Act is titled the "Emergency Medical Services Support Act" and defines "community-based emergency medical services" as any regional, State, or local emergency medical services system. Additionally, it establishes a Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services. The Emergency Medical Services Support Act establishes the Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services (Interagency Committee on EMS) to coordinate federal agencies involved in emergency medical services, identify needs, create grant programs, streamline support processes, and prioritize based on needs. Membership includes a representative from the National Highway. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services (Interagency Committee on EMS) includes representatives from various federal agencies such as the Department of Transportation, Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Federal Emergency Management Agency, Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Department of Defense, Federal Communications Commission, and more. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration provides administrative support to the Interagency Committee on EMS and the Advisory Council, including scheduling meetings, maintaining records, and selecting a chairperson annually. The Interagency Committee on EMS meets as determined by the Administrator of the National Highway Transportation Administration or on a quarterly basis with the Advisory Council. SEC. 4. FEDERAL INTERAGENCY COMMITTEE ON EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council is established with up to 13 members selected by the Interagency Committee on EMS. The Advisory Council ensures representation from urban and rural settings and diverse sectors of the EMS community. A chairperson is chosen annually, members serve without compensation but receive expense reimbursement, and meetings are held quarterly. Annual reports are required. The Interagency Committee on EMS and the Advisory Council must each submit an annual report to Congress. The report should cover current support for community-based EMS providers, coordination of EMS programs between federal agencies, a needs assessment for improving EMS systems at state and local levels, recommendations for new grants or programs, and suggestions for additional congressional support for community-based EMS.
